utterances: You're teaching now at Columbia.
What's the first thing you tell your students to do when they go out in the field?
It's funny, I had a parent of a student call me after the book came out and said you're not sending my kid to hang out with crack-dealing gangs, are you?
I said no, I'm not doing that.
But I am telling them that there's a value in stepping outside the ivory tower or going across the street.
I send them into Harlem.
I send them to the Upper East Side to talk to the rich kids.
I really think it's important that we get our students out of the classroom and engaged with people one on one, because that is really where I think the fount of knowledge will come from.
Sudhir, thanks a lot.
Oh, thank you.
It's been a pleasure.
Sudhir Venkatesh is the author of ""Gang Leader for a Day: A Rogue Sociologist Takes to the Streets."" He's also a sociology professor at Columbia University.
From NPR News it's Day to Day.
New numbers out from the Commerce Department today bring a bit of good news to the grim economic landscape.
The Gross Domestic Product, or GDP, rose 1.9 percent in the second quarter.
Economists had expected a slightly better number, but hey at least it's moving in the right direction.
Marketplace's Nancy Marshall-Genzer joins us now.
Nancy, what is driving this economic growth?
Well, Alex, rising exports are a major factor.
The dollar is low and that makes U.S.
goods cheaper for foreign buyers.
Exports of U.S.
agricultural products were up.
Also we're selling more planes abroad.
More foreign companies are building factories in the U.S.
because it's cheaper for them to make things like cars here and then sell them here.
There are some not so obvious things.
We count exports that are soaring because of the weak dollar.
Global Insight Chief Economist Nariman Behravesh says tourism is a good example.

There have been disclosures.
But I think everybody needs to keep in mind that these hospital systems around the country are not - mostly not public systems.
They are generally organized as private nonprofits, so they're not subject to Public Information Act.
They are subject to regulatory actions, so there are certain disclosures that get made.
But in terms of the exact nature of the business deals and the exact amount involved, that's not entirely clear at this point.
Jayne Miller, we have to note in passing that we talk regularly on this program about huge health care costs in this country and how one source of the high costs would happen to be hospitals.
But let me just ask about Mayor Pugh.
We mentioned that she took a leave of absence.
She said, I believe, that's for health reasons, right?
Has she directly responded to the allegations themselves?

She held a news conference last Thursday upon being released from the hospital after being treated for a bout of pneumonia and discussed the University of Maryland Medical System transactions where she accounted for about 58- to 60,000 books over this period of time.
The problem is that that's not the whole story.

And what has really now emerging - the questions that surround Mayor Catherine Pugh are whether she has properly disclosed her relationships with different business entities when she is sitting on the city's spending board, for example, when she was in the state Legislature and taking action and legislative action and executive action involving the very same entities.
Wow.
That's where this story is headed now.
OK.
We'll keep following.
Jayne Miller, thanks so much.
Thank you.
She's with WBAL in Baltimore.
Joe Biden is speaking out.

The former vice president and potential 2020 Democratic candidate is responding to allegations from women who say he made close physical contact that was unwanted and made them feel uncomfortable or embarrassed.
Biden released a video on Twitter today.
(SOUNDBITE OF ARCHIVED RECORDING)
Social norms have begun to change.
They've shifted.
And the boundaries of protecting personal space have been reset.
And I get it.
I get it.
I hear what they're saying.
I understand it.
And I'll be much more mindful.
That's my responsibility - my responsibility, and I'll meet it.
Joining us now is NPR's lead political editor Domenico Montanaro.
Hi, Domenico.
Hey there, Ari.
We all watched that video this afternoon.
What did you make of it?
Well, you know, he acknowledged that he did make women feel uncomfortable at various times.

He said that he's always tried, though, to make a human connection with people, and that's why he has been so physical with folks, even though a lot of this is stuff that we've seen in public previously.
And I have to say that the fact that he's trying to save his candidacy before he even gets in...
Right.
...Is not a great sign for him.
And the first woman to come forward with an allegation responded this afternoon.
What did she say?
She did.
That was Lucy Flores.

She said that in 2014, just for some background here, at an event that's - when she was running for lieutenant governor of Nevada, Biden put his hands on her shoulders, smelled her hair, kissed the top of her head and got too close and made her feel uncomfortable.

This afternoon, she responded to Biden's video and said that she's glad that the vice president acknowledges that he made women feel uncomfortable but that given his long work on behalf of women, he should, quote, ""be aware of how important it is to take personal responsibility for inappropriate behavior.
And yet, he hasn't apologized to the women he made feel uncomfortable.
And she's not the only one.
There are three other women who have come forward to say that they had interactions with the vice president that made them feel uncomfortable at various events.
So as you say, he appears to be trying to save a candidacy that he has not yet declared.
Right.
What does this mean for that?
Well, look; a month ago, most people thought that he would run.
Now it's not that clear.
He's really struggling to get past this.
You see it even in his response.
He hasn't been able to kind of put out a response, even before he even gets in here, if he were to do so, that has been satisfying to the people who, ostensibly, he would need to win over.
And I think it really highlights for a lot of people that this is a huge generational divide within the Democratic Party.
Is 2019 really here for this kind of behavior from Joe Biden?
Even though he's saying that he has learned from it, he's not going to do that in the future, is this a party that wants, you know, Biden to be the standard-bearer...
Well...
...When it's been grappling with everything President Trump has done?
And in this moment, we are looking at the biggest, most diverse field of candidates ever in history.
How does this fit into that context?
Right.

And I think that's the biggest thing because a lot of these older Democrats who like Joe Biden think that he could win in places like the Midwest and give them a good chance to beat President Trump because of his blue-collar roots and his natural appeal.
But that's not something that's necessarily the thing that younger activists - Democrats really want to hear.
That's NPR lead political editor Domenico Montanaro.
Thanks, Domenico.
You're so welcome.

And it involves cows and climate change.
Julia Simon reports from the Nigerian capital, Abuja.

It did.
Although, we didn't get quite the kick we hoped for from those checks.
Spending did go up on things like shoes, clothing, furniture and household appliances.
Shocking as this is, though, Alex, people may have saved some of the money from their rebate checks, or set it aside to spend later, and that's what Mark Vitner thinks.
He's senior economist at Wachovia.
Many people may have held on to some of their stimulus checks and spending did not increase anywhere near as much as it would have if consumers spent every bit of their stimulus check.
And so folks may have held on to some of that to spend on back to school purchases.
And school is coming up, so does it look like the checks will continue to boost the economy?
Yes, we could get a little bump in the third quarter, but after that all bets are off.
Mark Vitner thinks growth is going to trail off for the last quarter of the year.
And that's what happened in the fourth quarter of last year right?
Certainly is.
In fact, the government revised its numbers downward for that fourth quarter of 2007.
It revised them downward by saying that GDP actually fell two-tenths of a percent at the end of last year.
Now, Alex, it doesn't mean that we're in a recession.
That's generally defined as two consecutive quarters of falling GDP numbers.
We did not have that.
We just had the one negative quarter.

Still, the revised fourth quarter number is the worst showing since the third quarter of 2001, when the economy was actually in a recession, and some economists say if it weren't for exports we would be in a recession right now.
Now Alex there is a bit of, I suppose you could call it good news.
One area of growth, the government sector, grew at a 3.4 percent annual rate in the second quarter.
That added about a half a percentage point to the GDP.
